results.title: BMX is life
results.creator_credit: Harley Van Belkolm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Riding and doing tricks on his BMX is when Harley Van Belkolm feels free. He provides some insight into this passion of his, the culture that surrounds it and why he wouldn’t be doing anything else.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harley Van Belkolm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Becoming me
results.creator_credit: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Tyson Cunningham can’t express himself, music does it for him. Although he has long given up dreams of fronting a band like his brother, music is still everything to him, and expresses his emotional life like nothing else.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tyson Cunningham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: prelude to revolution, 1904-1905
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Sam Spiegel and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Focuses on the years 1904-1905. Shows some of the causes of the Russian revolution that were visible more than a decade before Lenin arrived at the Finland station. Reveals the extreme contrasts of Russia, the role of the Czar, the workers, the revolutionaries and the peasants. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman, Laurence Olivier.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: war and the fall of the Czar, 1914-1917
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Sam Spiegel and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Shows the intertwining of Russia’s war policy abroad with her chaos at home. Tells how Nicholas went to the front with the army, leaving Alexandra to rule and how she thought only of her son’s possible cure. Ends with Czar’s abdication. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman.

results.title: Nicholas and Alexandra: the Bolshevik Victory, 1917
results.creator_credit: Franklin J. Schaffner, Sam Spiegel and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Western Civilization”.
Covers the October Revolution and shows the radicalisation, counter revolution and civil war. Explains that Lenin returned to Russia, promising peace and a new socialist order. Shows how Kerensky became powerless and ends with the Czar’s execution. Uses excerpts from the film “Nicholas and Alexandra (1971) starring Michael Jayston, Janet Suzman, Jack Hawkins, Ian Holm to tell the story of the Bolshevik victory.

results.title: Bismarck: Germany from blood and iron
results.creator_credit: John irvin, Malcolm B. Heyworth, Learning Corporation of America and Chatsworth Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Western Civilization”.
Nationalism is a major force in modern history, and national unity has often been forged in war. This film traces the step-by-step creation of modern Germany and suggests its implications for the rest of the world. In 1815 there were thirty-nine separate German-speaking states in a confederation under Austrian leadership. By 1871 a united German nation was born, led by the northern state of Prussia and the man who was to be its first Chancellor - Otto Von Bismarck. Relaxing with two American friends, the architect of the new Germany recollects the steps which led up to unification, which is told in a series of flashbacks. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John irvin, Malcolm B. Heyworth, Learning Corporation of America and Chatsworth Film Productions

results.title: A Matter of conscience: Henry VIII and Sir Thomas More
results.creator_credit: Fred Zimmerman and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Western Civilization”.
An edited version of ‘A Man for All Seasons’ concentrating on the historic clash between Henry VIII and Sir Thomas More as a prototypical confrontation between the power of the state and the individual who chooses to oppose it.
